Celeste Benitez, Secretaria de Educación. 1992. p. 145. – 1923) was a Puerto Rican musician and composer of danzas. ==Early years== Julio Carlos de Arteaga Matheu (a.k.a., Julio Carlos Arteaga Matheu) was born in Ponce, Puerto Rico, on 29 October 1867 to Diego Arteaga Lopez, from Venezuela, and Isabel Matheu. He had two siblings, Juan Jose and Herminia Isabel. ==Professional career== A composer and musician from Puerto Rico, Arteaga's musical performances were not limited to Puerto Rico, and he traveled to New York City often performing there as well.Guide to the Genoveva de Arteaga Papers: Genoveva de Arteaga (1898–1991) Archives of the Puerto Rican Diaspora. Hunter College. City University of New York. page 3. November 1991. Retrieved 2 March 2018. Among his many musical awards, at a music competition in Paris he won First Prize in Piano Performance in 1890.La Educacion Musical Primaria en Puerto Rico. Léster López Nieves. Monograph. University La Salle. 8 June 2013. ==Music school == After teaching music theory and music lessons out of his home for a while,La Educacion Musical Primaria en Puerto Rico. Léster López Nieves. 8 June 2013. Retrieved 2 March 2018. in 1898 he co-founded the Asociación Musical de Puerto Rico (Puerto Rico Music Association). In that same year he and Felipe Gutiérrez Espinosa, another outstanding Puerto Rican composer, approached Governor Guy V. Henry with a proposal to establish a music institute in San Juan. While the project never materialized due to lack of interest in Governor Henry's administration, it gave birth to the idea of establishing music schools independent of the public instruction system.Historia. Conservatorio de Musica de Puerto Rico. Puerto Rico Music Conservatory. Retrieved 2 March 2018. Together with his wife, Nicolasa Torruellas, he founded the Arteaga Academy in Ponce, where they taught piano, music theory, organ, and voice, among others.Guide to the Genoveva de Arteaga Papers: Genoveva de Arteaga (1898–1991). Archives of the Puerto Rican Diaspora. Centro de Estudios Puertorriqueños. Hunter College. New York City. page 3. November 1991. Retrieved 2 March 2018. Among his pupils was Monserrate Ferrer Otero ("Monsita Ferrer"),Monserrate Ferrer Otero. La Danza Puertorriquena: El Hogar de la Danza Puertorriqueña. Retrieved 2 March 2018. and Mercedes Arias. This last one, Mercedes Arias, was the failed love of Juan Morel Campos, the woman he loved but could never marry,Juan Morel Campos. El Hogar de la La Danza Puertorriqueña. 2016. Retrieved 7 March 2018. and on whom Morel Campos found inspiration for several of his great masterpiece danzas, including "Maldito Amor" (Damned Love), "No Me Toques" (Don't Touch Me) and "Alma Sublime" (Sublime Soul).Mercedes Arias: entre las glorias de la historia musical de Ponce. La Perla del Sur. Ponce, Puerto Rico. Year 35. Issue 1788. Pages 8–9. 7 March 2018. Retrieved 7 March 2018. He returned to New York City where he had studied violin and works as organist at St. Patrick's Cathedral from 1920 to 1923.Armando Torres Leon. Los Municipios de Puerto Rico y Su Historia y Su Cultura: PONCE, La Perla del Sur. Santurce, Puerto Rico: Departamento de Educación de Puerto Rico. Programa Regular de Educación. Programa Editorial. Celeste Benitez, Secretaria de Educación. 1992. p. 145. He died in New York City in 1923. ==Family life== Arteaga married Daría Nicolasa Torruellas, also a musician, with whom he had five children, four boys (including Pedro [1903–], and Julio Carlos [1907–]), and a girl. The girl, Genoveva, would become an outstanding musician herself. ==Legacy== * There is a relief sculpture on the right front wall face of the Concha Acustica de Ponce engraved with his face and shoulders as well as his name. His is the center sculpture: to his left is Antonio Paoli and to the right is Juan Ríos Ovalle. * A music school in New York City has his name.Guide to the Genoveva de Arteaga Papers: Genoveva de Arteaga (1898–1991) Archives of the Puerto Rican Diaspora. Centro de Estudios Puertorriqueños. Hunter College. City University of New York. p.4. November 1991.
